TITLE: CCU Resident Progress Note
   Chief Complaint: cardiogenic shock
   24 Hour Events:
   - renal came by thought that needed CVVH for fluid removal, had femoral
   line placed to for dialysis
   - respiratory status clinically worsening with respiration to 40s
   - urine lytes Urine urea 169, urine creatinine 132, na < assay, urine
   osm 340, FeNa < 1%
   - urine eos were negative
   - urine lytes: feurea 7% all suggestive of pre-renal etiology likely in
   the setting of poor forward flow with cardiogenic
   - patient intubated in the setting of continued tachycardia  and
   worsening respiratory distress: started neosynephrine prophylactically
   prior to intubation to prevent from dropping pressure
   - started on fentayl and versed for sedation
   - patient got succinylcholine, etomidate as well as 2 x 1mg bolus of
   neo during intubation
   - post intubation chest x-ray demonstrates - ett terminate at thoracic
   inlet 4.5cm from carina, ogt in stomach. other lines stable. slightly
   increased peripheral left interstitial markings suggest mild edema.
   .

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM,
   hyperlipidemia and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting
   and ongoing CP, found to have elevated CE and EKG changes without any
   acute infarct seen on cardiac catherization.
   .
   # Shock: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely elevated
   filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Also cool
   and clamped down on exam.  Etiology possibly hypotension (unclear
   precipitant) leading to global ischemia and poor CO and elevated
   filling pressures. Patient had balloon pump placed during cardiac
   catherization.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60
   - levofed to maintain blood pressure control for now
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  FeNa 7% and
   feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward
   flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received
   contrast at OSH, however suspsect that this effect is too early.
   Patient did not put out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.
   Renal was consulted and recommended starting CVVH in order to remove
   fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Currently appears euvolemic.
   Remains hypoxic, however likely related to splinting in setting of L
   rib fx.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -1 liter per day with CVVH
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # Hypotension: BP ranging in 90s-100s here.  Extremities are cool,
   concerning for cardiogenic shock.  Has evidence of end-organ damage
   with ARF and urine output dropped off despite lasix drip.  Patient had
   intraaortic balloon pump placed in the cath lab.
   - pressors as required to maintain MAP > 60
   - Holding BB for now
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1)
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)
   DISPO: CCU for now

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. The patient presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes (CE) and EKG changes without any acute infarct seen on cardiac catheterization.

The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock, characterized by hypotension, low cardiac index (CI), and extremely elevated filling pressures. He has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy and likely ischemic heart disease, as evidenced by the presence of three-vessel disease (3VD) on catheterization. The patient's left ventricular (LV) function is significantly depressed, and he has global hypokinesis.

The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by an increase in creatinine levels from 1.9 at OSH to 3.6 on admission. The patient has a history of anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is at risk for rebleeding given his recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).

The patient's blood pressure is ranging in the 90s-100s, and extremities are cool, which is concerning for cardiogenic shock. He has evidence of end-organ damage with acute renal failure (ARF) and decreased urine output despite lasix drip. The patient had an intraaortic balloon

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall. He presents with nausea and vomiting and is diagnosed with cardiogenic shock. The patient has been treated with a balloon pump, intra-aortic balloon pump placement, and various medications. He also has acute renal failure, liver abnormalities, and hypotension. The patient's current condition is critical, and he is being closely monitored in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's primary condition is cardiogenic shock, which can lead to poor tissue perfusion, organ dysfunction, and potentially death if not managed properly.
2. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient has an elevated creatinine level and low urine output, indicating renal dysfunction. ARF can progress to chronic renal failure if not treated promptly.
3. Liver abnormalities: The patient has significantly elevated liver enzymes, which may be secondary to cardiogenic shock or other factors. Close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent further liver damage.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure remains in the 90s-100s, indicating persistent hypotension. This can compromise tissue perfusion and increase the risk of end-organ damage.
5. Infection: Prolonged hospitalization, invasive lines, and immunosuppression can increase the risk of hospital-acquired infections such

Summary: The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall who presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing cardiogenic shock. The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. He also has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy with previous ejection fraction of 25%. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock with hypotension, low cardiac index, and elevated filling pressures. He has a balloon pump placed to augment coronary perfusion and is being managed with continuous intravenous medications. The patient's renal function is impaired, likely due to hypotension, poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure, and cardiogenic shock. He is undergoing continuous venovenous hemodialysis (CVVH) to remove fluid and maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP). The patient's liver function tests are significantly elevated, likely secondary to cardiogenic shock. He is also at risk for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to pulmonary edema and requires mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and is receiving insulin and other diabetic medications. He also has a history of anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is being managed with erythropoietin and iron supplementation. The patient's hyperlipidemia is being managed with statin therapy. The patient has a history of CAD, with three-vessel disease demonstrated on cardiac catheterization. The patient also had a recent non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) in the setting of acute gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), which was treated medically. Laboratory results show elevated cardiac biomarkers, consistent with myocardial injury.

The patient has been placed on a balloon pump to augment coronary perfusion.    - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.

   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever

   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put

   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperlipidemia, and recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). The patient presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes (CE) and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition includes cardiogenic shock, septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute hepatitis, acute renal failure (ARF), and anemia. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. He is also on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) for renal support.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 102.8°F (39.3°C) initially, currently 101.8°F (38.8°C)
- Heart rate: 89 bpm
- Blood pressure: 88/53 mmHg (69/40 mmHg at times)
- Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 99% on FiO2 of 50%

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, liver enzymes, and troponin T. The patient's renal function is impaired, with an elevated creatinine level of 3.6 mg/dL.

The patient has multiple lines and catheters in place, including PIV lines, L femoral HD line, R femoral PA catheter, and an IABP line. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including vasopressin, vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, fentanyl, heparin sodium, calcium gluconate (CRRT), lansoprazole, midazolam, and others.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently in the CCU.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral neuropathy. He presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient has been diagnosed with cardiogenic shock, sepsis, respiratory distress, acute hepatitis, acute renal failure, and anemia. He has multiple comorbidities and is currently critically ill in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low cardiac output and elevated filling pressures indicate cardiogenic shock. This condition can lead to organ hypoperfusion and failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia and signs of systemic inflammation, indicating sepsis. Sepsis can progress to septic shock, leading to further organ dysfunction and potential death.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's rising creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure. This condition can worsen if not treated promptly, leading to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.
4. Respiratory Distress: The patient requires mechanical ventilation due to pulmonary edema and rib fractures. Extubation will depend on the resolution of respiratory distress and adequate volume status.
5. Acute Hepatitis: The patient has significantly elevated liver enzymes, indicating acute hepatitis.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's medical complications and conditions include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and recent myocardial infarction (MI), which likely contributed to the development of cardiogenic shock. The patient's low blood pressure, decreased cardiac output, and elevated biomarkers indicate ongoing cardiac dysfunction.

2. Septic shock: The patient developed septic shock, likely due to bacteremia caused by GPC. This is supported by the presence of fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and organ dysfunction.

3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed left-sided infiltrates and sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip, indicating the possibility of VAP. Intubation and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of developing pneumonia.

4. Acute hepatitis: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are significantly elevated, suggesting acute hepatitis. This could be secondary to cardiogenic shock or another underlying cause.

5. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's baseline creatinine level was 1.9, which increased to 3.6 on arrival. With no known history of renal disease, the etiology of AKI is likely due to hypotension and poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure and cardiogenic shock. CVVH has been initiated to remove excess fluid and support renal function.

6. Coronary artery disease (CAD): The patient has a history of CAD, including a recent NSTEMI and 3-vessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient's elevated cardiac biomarkers suggest ongoing myocardial injury.

7. Dilated cardiomyopathy: The patient's bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV hypokinesis, indicating dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic in nature.

8. Pulmonary edema: The patient required intubation due to significant pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF.

9. Thrombophlebitis: The patient has thrombophlebitis on the right hand, which could be a source of infection.

10. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and was on Vytorin at home. In the setting of NSTEMI, atorvastatin 80mg has been started.

11. Peripheral neuropathy: The patient has a history of peripheral neuropathy and was on gabapentin as an outpatient.

12. Anemia: The patient has anemia, likely chronic disease-related, with low iron levels and elevated ferritin.

13. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, indicating hyperglycemia.

14. Falls: The patient has a recent history of falls, which could have contributed to their current condition.

It is important to note that this summary is based on the provided information, and further evaluation by a healthcare professional is necessary for an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, recent myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a fall. He presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing cardiogenic shock. The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. 

Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's shock picture is a combination of cardiogenic with distributive. He is on a balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP >60 and goal CI 2.0, and may attempt to wean down to 2:1. Levofed was switched to vasopressin due to recurrent ventricular ectopy with non-perfusing NSVT.

2. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has GPC bacteremia. There is ongoing bacteremia, likely contributing to septic shock. Empiric vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam are being dosed for CVVH. Sources of infection need to be investigated, including thrombophlebitis on the right hand and possible aspiration pneumonia. A PA line needs to be removed.

3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has left-sided infiltrate and sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN dip. He will continue to be intubated and fluid will be pulled

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK: Presented with hypotension, low CI and extremely
   elevated filling pressures, all consistent with cardiogenic shock.
   Also cool and clamped down on exam.  Patient had balloon pump placed
   during cardiac catherization to augment coronary perfusion.  With
   balloon pump off SBP maintained in 100s.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off levophed PVR <
   WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing bacteremia
   there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall + pulmonary
   edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory distress and
   tiring from effort
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # ARF: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On arrival patient with
   Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on
   urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor forward flow in
   setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Also received contrast at
   OSH, however suspect that this effect is too early. Patient did not put
   out to lasix drip at maximum doses or Diorel.  Renal was consulted and
   started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].  On
   procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA
   cath
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient experienced cardiogenic shock, which was treated with a balloon pump to augment coronary perfusion. He also developed septic shock due to a GPC bacteremia and required empiric antibiotics. The patient had respiratory distress, possibly due to rib fractures from a fall and pulmonary edema from acute systolic congestive heart failure, leading to intubation. He also had acute hepatitis with significantly elevated liver function tests, acute renal failure with an elevated creatinine level, and a history of chronic kidney disease. The patient's coronary arteries were found to have three-vessel disease during the cardiac catheterization. He has been receiving various medications and treatments, including cardiac enzymes, statins, heparin, and aspirin. The patient's current condition is complicated by multiple medical complications, including cardiogenic shock, septic shock, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus, and other comorbidities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's initial presentation was cardiogenic shock, which is a serious condition where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. This can lead to organ damage

He was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient is currently in the ICU for cardiogenic shock, sepsis/bacteremia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and coronary artery disease. He has multiple medical complications including hypotension, poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock, sepsis, respiratory distress, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low blood pressure and poor cardiac output indicate cardiogenic shock, which can lead to organ hypoperfusion and failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has a confirmed coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. Sepsis can progress rapidly and may lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed left-sided infiltrates and sputum with Gram-negative rods, Gram-positive cocci, and diplococci. VAP can increase the risk of mortality and should be treated promptly with appropriate antibiotics.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Switched levofed to vasopressin [**1-25**] recurrent ventricular ectopy with
   a non-perfusing NSVT, consider adding levophed back if
      needed
   - Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Pt with GPC bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once off
   levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock. Given ongoing
   bacteremia there is likely a component of septic shock.
   - Continue screening BCx until cleared
   - Empiric vanco + pip/tazo dosed for CVVH
   - Investigate sources for infection. Has thrombophlebitis on R hand. ?
   Aspiration PNA. Lines are new but may be source of infection. Will try
   and get PA line out.
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function (planned for today)
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing chest pain. The patient has elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition includes cardiogenic shock, sepsis/bacteremia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and coronary artery disease. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a balloon pump in place to increase coronary perfusion.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F), heart rate of 83 beats per minute, blood pressure of 77/47 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 98% on 40% FiO2, and a CVP of 8 mmHg. His labs show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, lactate, liver enzymes, and cardiac biomarkers.

The patient's plan includes continuing pressors to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP), CVVH for renal support, daily renal recommendations, avoiding nephrotoxins, and continuing ASA, statin, and hepatic drip. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently in the CCU.

Potential medical complications that can arise

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock with a combination of cardiogenic and distributive components. He is being treated with a balloon pump and vasopressin, and his goal MAP is greater than 60 and CI of 2.0. There is also a concern for septic shock due to ongoing bacteremia, and the patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy and previous ejection fraction of 25%. He had a significant pulmonary edema requiring intubation and now has a PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics. His renal function is impaired with a baseline creatinine of 1.9, which has increased to 3.6. The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) due to acute kidney injury. There are concerns about ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and the patient's sputum culture shows growth of GNR, GPC, and GN dip.

Other medical conditions include acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral neuropathy. The patient has been started on atorv

   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Low-dose Dopamine added to Vasopressin yest for BP support -
   Cardiogenic shock is complicated by septic shock
 currently off
   dopamine since 3AM, IABP weaned to 3:1
   -
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once
   off levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - Continue vanco + low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed yest with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled. Unable
   to wean off IABP
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   - Continue Vanc/levo per ID recs
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presented with nausea, vomiting, and ongoing chest pain, and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. 

The patient has multiple medical complications including cardiogenic shock, sepsis/bacteremia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and coronary artery disease. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress and pulmonary edema. 

His vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.8°C, heart rate 83 bpm, blood pressure 77/47 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on supplemental oxygen. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, liver enzymes, creatinine, lactate, and cardiac biomarkers. Blood cultures have grown coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus. 

The patient's medical history includes a recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, acute gastrointestinal bleeding, and a history of dilated cardiomyopathy. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low blood pressure and elevated cardiac enzymes indicate a possible cardiogenic shock, which is a serious condition that occurs when the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall.
- The patient presented with nausea and vomiting and ongoing chest pain, which was found to be associated with elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes.
- The patient has been diagnosed with cardiogenic shock, sepsis/bacteremia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute hepatitis, and acute kidney injury.
- The patient's medical history includes a recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and acute gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), both treated medically.
- The patient underwent cardiac catheterization showing no evidence of acute infarct, but demonstrated global hypoperfusion in the setting of hypotension.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization.
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Cont. balloon pump, 1:1 with goal MAP>60 and goal CI 2.0, if
   possible, will try to wean down to 2:1 though his MAPS this
     morning are only in the low 60s.
   - Low-dose Dopamine added to Vasopressin for BP support - Cardiogenic
   shock is complicated by septic shock
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once
   off levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - Continue vanco + low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed yest with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled. Unable
   to wean off IABP
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   Has PA catheter to monitor hemodynamics.
   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   - repeat TTE pending to assess cardiac function (planned for today)
   - Daily CXR to assess PA cath and balloon location
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse this morning (<25)
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, nutrition consult for TFs
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L femoral HD line, R femoral PA
   cath
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)
   DISPO: CCU for now

Summary:
The patient's progress note indicates that they are experiencing multiple medical complications. Here are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient has a history of CAD, recent MI, and GIB, which may have contributed to cardiogenic shock. They are currently on a balloon pump and receiving vasopressor support.

2. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and sepsis. Antibiotics have been initiated, and daily surveillance blood cultures are being continued.

3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has left-sided infiltrate and sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN dip, suggesting VAP. Intubation will continue for now, and efforts will be made to wean off the ventilator once the patient's volume status is controlled.

4. Acute Hepatitis: The patient has elevated liver function tests, possibly secondary to cardiogenic shock. Liver function tests are being trended, and low-dose Tylenol is being given for fever.

5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's baseline renal function is unknown, but their serum creatinine has increased from 1.9 at OSH to 3.6. CVVH has been started to remove fluid and improve renal function.

6. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient has a history of CAD

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of type II diabetes mellitus, renal failure, and septic shock. He presented to the ICU with severe sepsis and was found to have evidence of endocarditis. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) support. He has undergone multiple interventions including central venous catheter placement, arterial line placement, and renal replacement therapy.

The patient's vital signs remain unstable with hypotension and tachycardia. His blood glucose levels have been elevated. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and liver enzymes. Cardiac markers such as troponin-T and CK-MB are elevated, indicating ongoing myocardial injury. Renal function tests reveal worsening renal failure.

The patient continues to require aggressive management with vasopressin, dopamine, and IABP support for hemodynamic stability. Antibiotic therapy has been adjusted based on sensitivities. Repeat echocardiogram is pending to assess the progression of endocarditis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Endocarditis: The patient's presentation suggests evidence of endocarditis, which can lead to further deterioration of cardiac function and systemic infection.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's persistent hypotension and tachycardia indicate ongoing septic shock, which can result in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
3. Acute Renal Failure

   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have

   on CVVH
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**]. Once
   off levophed PVR < WNL consistent with a distributive shock.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - switched vanco to nafcillin yesterday as per ID with sensitivies
   - Continue low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed yest with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled.
   - weaned off IABP yesterday
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA:
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
 was unable to do pressure support trial
   yesterday will try today, check RISBI in am
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   - Continue Nafcillin/levo/gentamicin per ID recs
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock which continue to improve.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6. No known h/o renal
   disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology includes hypotension, poor
   forward flow in setting of heart failure, cardiogenic shock.  Renal was
   consulted and started CVVH in order to remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.  Patient has had has elevated fingersticks.  Started patient on
   long acting Lantus yesterday and increased sliding scale.
   - consider uptitiration of lantus as required
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   Patient got 1 unit of blood yesterday without appropriate bump in
   hematocrit.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools
   - Transfuse for HCT <25
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presents with nausea, vomiting, ongoing chest pain, elevated cardiac enzymes, and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient is currently experiencing cardiogenic shock and septic shock due to coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. 

The patient's current condition includes ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and coronary artery disease. He has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs show hypotension and tachycardia. Laboratory results indicate elevated levels of white blood cells, liver enzymes, creatinine, lactate, and cardiac biomarkers.

The patient's medical management includes vasopressin for cardiogenic shock, antibiotics for sepsis, nafcillin for Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia, CVVH for acute kidney injury, and insulin for glycemic control. The patient's lines have been changed, and his dialysis catheter was placed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening cardiogenic shock, septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and hepatic dysfunction. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, fluid status, and laboratory values will be crucial in managing these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current medical conditions and potential complications are as follows:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is experiencing cardiogenic shock due to acute systolic congestive heart failure and ongoing chest pain. The patient requires vasopressor support and an intra-aortic balloon pump to maintain adequate blood pressure and coronary perfusion.

2. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has a confirmed coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. Antibiotics have been changed to nafcillin and gentamicin, with plans to continue vancomycin and levofloxacin. Daily surveillance blood cultures are also being obtained.

3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed left-sided infiltrates and sputum cultures positive for GNR, GPC, and GN dip. The patient will continue to be intubated and receive appropriate antibiotics.

4. Acute Hepatitis: The patient has significantly elevated liver function tests, suggesting acute hepatitis. Trending LFTs and continuing pressors to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP) are recommended.

5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's baseline renal function is unknown, but they have a creatinine level of 2.5 on admission, which has increased to 3.6. CVVH has been initiated to remove excess fluid and treat AKI.

   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization now with cardiogenic and septic shock
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:  IABP d/c
d on [**2-10**].
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.  Needs Aline to be placed.
   - Patient only maintained on low dose Vasopressin. Goal MAPs >60.  Will
   attempt to wean vasopressin today.
   - unable to run patient more negative given borderline blood pressures
   on CVVH
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**].
   Febrile overnight with elevated WBC count.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - switched vanco to nafcillin yesterday as per ID with sensitivies
   Will d/w ID re temps, WBC count.
   - Continue low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed [**2-9**] with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled.
   - weaned off IABP [**2-10**]
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   .
   # PNEUMONIA: ? Community acquired given moraxella.
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
 was unable to do pressure support trial
   yesterday will try today, check RISBI in am
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH.
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   - Continue Nafcillin/levo/gentamicin per ID recs
   - Will try 60mg IV lasix today.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock which continue to improve.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
 wean today.
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   ..
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6, now improved on
   CVVH. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology
   includes hypotension, poor forward flow in setting of heart failure,
   cardiogenic shock.  Renal was consulted and started CVVH in order to
   remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now.  Per renal plan to continue CVVH until UOP
   1000cc/day.
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.  Patient has had has elevated fingersticks.  Started patient on
   long acting Lantus yesterday and increased sliding scale.  BGs 400
   today.
   - Will need to start insulin gtt for better BG control today with q1H
   finger sticks.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   Patient got 1 unit of blood yesterday without appropriate bump in
   hematocrit.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools.  Negative so far.
   - Transfuse for HCT <25.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, TFs at goal.

   placed.

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and recent fall. He presented with nausea and vomiting and is now experiencing cardiogenic shock and septic shock. The patient has multiple comorbidities including pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's condition indicates cardiogenic shock, which is a severe drop in blood pressure that can lead to organ failure.
2. Septic Shock: The presence of sepsis and coagulase-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia suggests the possibility of septic shock, which can result in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress, left-sided infiltrate, and sputum culture indicating Moraxella may indicate community-acquired pneumonia. This can progress to severe pneumonia or lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to endotracheal intubation.
4. Acute Hepatitis: The significantly elevated liver function tests suggest acute hepatitis. It is crucial to identify the cause and manage the patient appropriately to prevent further liver damage.
5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's worsening renal function, as indicated by increased creatinine levels, suggests AKI. This could be due to hypotension, poor renal perfusion, or cardiogenic

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presented with nausea, vomiting, and ongoing chest pain. He was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. He is now experiencing cardiogenic shock and septic shock.

The patient has several medical complications, including pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and anemia. He also has a history of peripheral neuropathy and hyperlipidemia. His vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with pressure support. He has multiple lines and tubes inserted, including central venous catheters, arterial lines, and a urinary catheter.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, liver enzymes, lactate, and cardiac biomarkers. His kidney function is impaired, as indicated by an elevated creatinine level. His coagulation profile shows a prolonged PT/INR and PTT.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotic therapy for sepsis, CVVH for acute kidney injury, insulin for hyperglycemia, and anticoagulation for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. He is being closely monitored for various parameters, including fluid balance, hemodynamics, and respiratory status.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and he

   - Changed to insulin drip with better glycemic control

   Assessment and Plan
   67 y/o M with PMH of CAD s/p MI, DM, hyperlipidemia and recent fall who
   presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing CP, found to have
   elevated CE and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac
   catherization now with cardiogenic and septic shock
   .
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK:  IABP d/c
d on [**2-10**].
   - Shock picture now is a combination of cardiogenic with
   distributative.
   - Patient only maintained on low dose dopamine with MAPs >60.  Now off
   vasopressin
   - Low CVP and clinically dry so running even now
   - Consider stopped CVVH today and following volume status and
   electrolytes
   .
   # SEPSIS/BACTEREMIA: Coag + S. aureus bacteremia as of [**2190-2-8**].
   Febrile overnight with elevated WBC count.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures
   - switched vanco to nafcillin yesterday as per ID with sensitivies
   Will d/w ID re temps, WBC count.
   - Continue low dose gent dosed for CVVH
   - Continue levaquin for Morexella in sputum
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - Lines changed [**2-9**] with HD line changed and PA sheath pulled.
   - weaned off IABP [**2-10**]
   - Tylenol PRN for now to control temp and reduce drive for tachycardia
   and ectopy
   - Rising WBC overnight. Diff pending. Consider broadening ABx
   .
   # PNEUMONIA: ? Community acquired given moraxella.
   Ongoing Respiratory distress: Pt with rib fractures from fall +
   pulmonary edema from acute systolic CHF. Intubated [**1-25**] respiratory
   distress and tiring from effort. Now with left sided infiltrate and
   sputum with GNR, GPC, and GN Dip
   - Continue intubation for now
 was unable to do pressure support trial
   yesterday will try today, check RISBI in am
   - Continue to pull off fluid with CVVH.
   - Extubate as soon as possible once volume status controlled.
   - Continue Nafcillin/levo/gentamicin per ID recs
   - Tried lasix
   .
   # Acute hepatitis
 patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary
   to cardiogenic shock which continue to improve.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - continue pressors to maintain adequate MAP
 wean today.
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   .
   # Acute Kidney Injury: Unknown baseline.  Cr at OSH was 1.9.  On
   arrival patient with Cr 2.5 now trended up to 3.6, now improved on
   CVVH. No known h/o renal disease.  feNa < 1% on urine lytes. Etiology
   includes hypotension, poor forward flow in setting of heart failure,
   cardiogenic shock.  Renal was consulted and started CVVH in order to
   remove fluid.
   - continue CVVH for now.  Per renal plan to continue CVVH until UOP
   1000cc/day.
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has a history of CAD, 3VD on cath in [**8-31**].
   Recent NSTEMI in [**8-31**] in setting of acute GIB which was treated
   medically.  Now has significantly elevated biomarkers with associated
   EKG changes with a cath that demonstrates no evidence of acute infarct
   so likely that patient has global hypoperfusion in the setting of
   hypotension.  Stat bedside ECHO shows significantly depressed LV
   function, however did have severe global LV dysfunction on TTE on
   [**Month (only) **].  CK and MB trending up indicative of evolving MI, trop 3.88.
   Patient had balloon pump placed to increase coronary perfusion.
   - cont. ASA, statin, hep drip
   - hold beta blocker in the setting of hypotension
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # PUMP:  Has h/o dilated cardiomyopathy, likely ischemic given 3VD on
   cath.  Previous EF 25%. Bedside TTE suggests worsened global LV
   hypokinesis in setting of acute MI.  Had significant pulmonary edema
   requiring intubation.   - Monitor I/O with goal -100mL/hr with CVVH.
   - BB on hold given relative hypotension
   - cont aspirin, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold in the setting of hypotension and renal failure
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On 3 oral medications at home.  Received contrast at OSH so
   holding metformin.  In setting of acute illness will hold all oral
   meds.  Patient has had has elevated fingersticks.  Started patient on
   long acting Lantus yesterday and increased sliding scale.  BGs 400
   today.
   - Will need to start insulin gtt for better BG control today with q1H
   finger sticks.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   Patient got 1 unit of blood yesterday without appropriate bump in
   hematocrit.
   - Cont to follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - guaiac stools.  Negative so far.
   - Transfuse for HCT <25.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - cont atorvastatin
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube placed yesterday, TFs at goal.
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L IJ HD line, R IJ.  Needs Aline
   placed.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep gtt, PPI given intubated
   CODE: Full, confirmed with wife [**2-7**] (though pt would not want to be
   maintained on lifelong vent)
   CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 4098**] [**Name (NI) 4099**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4100**] (H), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4101**] (C)

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperlipidemia, and recent fall who presented with nausea and vomiting. He has ongoing cardiogenic shock and septic shock, requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission. The patient's medical history includes a previous myocardial infarction (MI), gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and dilated cardiomyopathy. He is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress and pulmonary edema. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, liver enzymes, and cardiac biomarkers. His renal function is impaired, and he is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). The patient is also being treated for suspected pneumonia, hepatitis, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's condition is complicated by cardiogenic shock, which is a result of his underlying CAD and dilated cardiomyopathy. This can lead to inadequate perfusion of vital organs and increased risk of mortality.
2. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely due to a bacterial infection, specifically coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. This infection may have originated from a central line or another source, leading to systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and septic shock.
3. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory distress and pulmonary edema

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperlipidemia, and recent fall. He presented with nausea and vomiting and ongoing chest pain (CP). The patient was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes (CE) and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. He is now experiencing cardiogenic and septic shock. The patient has been started on insulin for tight glycemic control. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis/Bacteremia: The patient has ongoing leukocytosis and bacteremia with coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). He is being treated with nafcillin and gentamicin. There is a concern for endocarditis, and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) has been scheduled.
2. Shock: The patient's shock picture is a combination of cardiogenic (regional variability) with distributive. He is maintained on low-dose dopamine and has been weaned off vasopressin. His low central venous pressure (CVP) and clinical dryness suggest running even without fluid administration.
3. Pneumonia: The patient is suspected to have community-acquired pneumonia caused by Moraxella catarrhalis. He is being treated with levofloxacin 750mg q48h.
4

TITLE: CCU Progress Note
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - Changed to insulin drip with better glycemic control
   - Catheter tip grew MSSA
   - ECHO showed EF 14% with a dilated left ventricle with severe global
   and regional systolic dysfunction, c/w multivessel CAD including a
   prior extensive inferior wall infarction. Mild right ventricular
   systolic dysfunction. Aortic stenosis, probably moderate. Mild aortic
   regurgitation. Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Mild pulmonary
   hypertension. Dilated aortic root.
   - Aline placed after several attempts
   - Initially weaned off vasopressin but MAPS in the 50s. Started
   dopamine 2.5 with improved MAPS

   tachypneic

   ultrafiltration
   - Running even given low CVP
   - Rising WBC. Concerning for Cdiff versus need to broaden Abx
   - Switched to midazolam drip for better sedation and improved liver
   function
   - PLT falling. Now 117 from 183 on admission
   - BCx still coming up positive concerning for endocarditis. TEE
   tomorrow (Friday). NPO after MN

He presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes without multivessel disease on cardiac catheterization. He is currently experiencing cardiogenic and septic shock, as well as respiratory failure. The patient also has suspected pneumonia, acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, hyperbilirubinemia, anemia (chronic kidney disease), hyperlipidemia, and peripheral neuropathy. He is on multiple medications including insulin, antibiotics, vasopressors, and renal dosed medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with blood pressure in the 80s, heart rate in the 80s, respiratory rate in the teens, and oxygen saturation at 100%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory values show leukocytosis, elevated liver enzymes, elevated lactate, low albumin, and abnormal kidney function tests.

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous myocardial infarction (MI), diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperlipidemia, and recent fall. He presents with nausea and vomiting and ongoing cardiogenic and septic shock. The patient has been diagnosed with MSSA bacteremia and is being treated with nafcillin and gentamicin. He also has pneumonia caused by Moraxella and is receiving levofloxacin.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors. He has cardiogenic shock due to multivessel CAD and a severely reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 14%. He also has severe global and regional systolic dysfunction, as well as mild right ventricular systolic dysfunction. Additionally, he has moderate aortic regurgitation, moderate to severe mitral regurgitation, mild pulmonary hypertension, and a dilated aortic root.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, requiring high levels of pressure support ventilation. He is intubated and sedated with midazolam. His arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.37, PaCO2 of 37, HCO3 of 21, base excess of -3, oxygen saturation of 100%, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 303.

The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). His blood urea nitrogen

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a recent fall. He presented with nausea and vomiting and was found to have elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes. He was diagnosed with cardiogenic shock and septic shock, and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome is suspected. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and he has a tracheostomy tube in place. He has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy with a previous ejection fraction of 25%. He also has acute hepatitis, acute kidney injury, and anemia of chronic disease. The patient's blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. He has a history of peripheral neuropathy and is on gabapentin. His most recent laboratory values show elevated white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, and renal dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's history of dilated cardiomyopathy and recent myocardial infarction put him at risk for cardiogenic shock, which has been confirmed by the presence of elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes. This condition can lead to poor tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction.

2. Septic shock: The patient has evidence of septic shock as indicated by positive blood cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. This condition can lead to systemic

   open sores.  TEE negative for endocarditis.
   - On nafcillin for MSSA.  Gentamicin stopped yesterday given negative
   TEE.
   - On levo for moroxella
   - Begin empiric treatment for C. diff with PO flagyl.
   - Check RUQ US given elevated T bili with low grade fever, WBC.
   - Continue daily surveillance blood cultures.  Follow micro data.
   - Could also consider sinus evaluation if no other source becomes
   apparent.
   - Add on urine culture
   # SHOCK:  Previously had been combination of cardiogenic plus septic,
   now appears to be more consistent with septic shock, althought does
   have very low EF.  IABP d/c
d on [**2-10**].  Continues to require dopamine
   for pressure support which is likely more related to infectious
   process.
   - Patient only maintained on low dose dopamine with MAPs >60.  Now off
   vasopressin
   - CVP 12 so room for diuresis with close monitoring of BPs.
   - Treatment of infectious processes as above.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE
   Tolerated pressure support [**2-12**] but did not tolerate secondary to
   agitation and tachypnea, switched back to AC.  No trials of pressure
   support overnight.
   - Needs further diuresis and then will trial PS.  Patient is 3L
   positive LOS.
   - Consider alternative forms of sedation to have less effect on BP.
   Try Ativan today.
   - Concentrate intake if possible.
   .
   # Acute hepatitis: patient with LFTs in the 1000s suspect  secondary to
   cardiogenic shock which continue to improve.
   - trend LFTs, improving
   - low dose Tylenol for fever
   .
   # Acute Kidney Injury:  Urinary output is improving.
   - continue CVVH for now.  Per renal plan to continue CVVH until UOP
   1000cc/day.
   - follow up daily renal recs
   - Renally dose meds
   ..
   #  HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA: Does not appear to be hemolysis, concern for RUQ
   source of infection given elevated bili.
   - Order portable RUQ u/s if more direct
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm, in the setting of respiratory distress patient
   developed sinus tachycardia to 130s
   - cont. tele, less ectopy.
   .
   # DM: On insulin gtt for tight glycemic control.
   - Continue insulin gtt for better BG control today with q1H finger
   sticks especially while on TF.
   - FS qid
   - HISS
   .
   # ANEMIA (CKD): Baseline appears to be in low 30s, was 31.6 in [**2186**].
   On procrit and iron as outpatient.  Hct slightly below baseline at 29.
   Given h/o recent GIB is at risk for rebleeding.  Repeated iron studies
   here with low iron 14 and elevated ferritin which suggests likely
   anemia of chronic disease rather than solely iron deficiency anemia.
   Patient got 1 unit of blood yesterday without appropriate bump in
   hematocrit.
   - guaiac stools.  Negative so far.
   - Transfuse for HCT <25.
   - Stop heparin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: On vytorin at home.  In setting of NSTEMI will start
   atorvastatin 80mg. On admission here HDL 36, LDL 56
   - Hold lipitor for now given multiple other medical problems.
   .
   # Peripheral neuropathy: On gabapentin as outpatient.
   - Restart once stable
   .
   FEN:  OG tube in place, TFs at goal.  Reglan for h/o gastroparesis.
   ACCESS: PIV's x 3 (20g x 2, 18g x 1), L IJ HD line, R IJ.  Aline in
   place.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep subq, PPI given intubated.  No need for bowel regimen
   as patient with soft stools.
